story.storykicker: To celebrate Mother's Day, Apple has created an advertisement which includes photographs taken from social media that have been shot on iPhone.
story.storybody:
The world and its cultural diversity can be a minefield for companies. Apple has found itself embroiled in a controversy over the company's latest ad that tries to hardsell the iPhone. While Tim Cook has always stood for the rights of LGBT and has been open about being gay, his company recently secretly modified its Mother's Day advertisement by removing a same sex couple from it when the advertisement was aired internationally. In the US version, the couple is part of the advertisement.

To celebrate Mother's Day, Apple has created an advertisement which includes photographs taken from social media that have been shot on iPhone. The US version of the 30 second advert showed the image of Melanie and Vanessa Roy from North Carolina, with their two kids , Jax Izzo and Ero Kix, lying on a bed and smiling at the camera.  However, the picture was removed from few international versions of it.

According to a Buzfeed report, the lesbian couple is missing in the German, Japanese, Turkish, Italian or French versions of the ad, while they can be seen in the Canadian, Australian, and Mexican version.

This isn't the first time Apple has altered an advertisement for international countries. According to 9to5mac, the Apple Watch "Date" ad featured tattoos in the American and French version. The Japanese version, however, did not. Essentially, Apple slightly modifying its ads to better suit the cultures of each individual country in which they air.

Although the stance is slightly surprising for Apple. Its CEO Tim Cook has been open its sexual orientation. He has even received several LGBT advocacy organisation's Visibility Award for playing a positive role model.
